oai_dc:dc.dc:title: "The Second Elder," poem by John Trotwood Moore
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: York, Alvin Cullum, 1887-1964; Moore, John Trotwood, 1858-1929; Clippings (Books, newspapers, etc.); Scrapbooks; Poetry
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The poem, printed in the Nashville Tennessean, recounts a dramatized version of Sergeant York's taking of the German machine gun position. The poem makes numerous biblical references as well as listing other prominent Tennessee military figures, including Andrew Jackson, David Crockett, John Sevier, and others.

Alvin York was one of the most decorated American soldiers in World War I. He was awarded a Medal of Honor and a French Croix de Guerre for taking a German machine gun nest and assisting in the capture of 132 German soldiers. John Trotwood Moore, an accomplished writer, was appointed the State Librarian and Archivist in March 1919 by Governor Albert Roberts.
